publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in ŠorčuqStadthöhleduring T III Š 79.02

sourceDesc.p: Transcription and references have been transferred from the "Text and Reference Database of the Tocharian A Language" (Gerd Carling Lund University) (funded by the Bank of Sweden Tercentenary Foundation and SCAS).
Transcription and translation are based on .

seg.seg: to me releasing a voice. (In the) Hells ... 4. || Then the venerable Maitreya, (the Buddha-god, made ...)

... to let the beings, that are attached (to the Kleśas), feel [world-]weariness, (a mirage). (This was) the city Ketumatī, houses, streets, beings and the achievements of the beings. So as (here there are cities, houses,

streets, beings and) the achievements (of the beings), just so the venerable Maitreya, the Buddha-god, (by his supernatural power let appear) other cities, houses, streets, beings and achievements of the beings.
Having seen this, the beings of Maitreya, these other exchanged beings in all their achievements resembling themselves one by one, are

amazed by this manifestation, (and) they say: || In the Kutsmāt-tune: || Oh what happiness! Oh what dignity! With [their] capability [having increased], even the[se] people grow. (These very beings are to us) doubly venerable persons.
Hey, you good ones, enjoy without concern the delights of mortal beings! 1. || Then, these beings of Maitreya, with increased pleasure, with increased achievement (by enjoying) increased delights
(He,) [ihr] Guten! Genießet ohne Sorge die irdischen Glücksgüter!
([You] good ones! Enjoy the earthly blessings without worry!

having become joyful beyond measure, men and women, big and small, went (together) with the powerful, highly capable, fashioned beings in the[ir] fashioned cities, houses, streets (in countless numbers).

|| In the Phulleṃ-tune: || By nature the Maitreya people are feeble companions. They make friends with them [i.e. the fashioned beings], [they are] very happy [and] rejoice. (They receive) homages for the festivity
Sie schließen mit ihnen [wtl. zu ihnen] Freundschaft, [sind] sehr glücklich [und] freuen sich.
They make friends with [lit. to] them, [are] very happy [and] are pleased.
... These call those hither and those call these hither. 1. Then suddenly fires appear from the fashioned cities. The jewel-cities, the jewel-(houses)
Diese rufen jene herbei, jene aber rufen diese.
These call for those, but those call these.

(the jewel-streets), with [all] possessions and achievements shrouded in flames, burn one and all as in the Raurava-hell. || Having seen this the Maitreya people (have become woeful) beyond all measure;
pointing out [the inhabitants] being in the jewel-cities, in the jewel-balconies, palaces, and towers, they say: Fie on the malicious (threefold Saṃsāra)! || In the Ṣeraśi Niṣkramānt tune: ||
Just like the eight hells together with [their] beings, shrouded by flame, glowed [and] burned, just so these miserable beings,

Wie [da eben] die acht Höllen mit [ihren] Wesen, von der Flamme eingehüllt, glühten [und] brannten, so verbrennen [bzw. werden verbrannt] diese unglücklichen Wesen ... verbrennen [bzw. werden verbrannt], von der Flamme eingehüllt, alle Lieben, sich zusammen umklammernd. Im ganzen Saṃsāra wird nicht [mehr?] Geburt verlangt, nicht ...

Just like the eight hells with [their] beings, wrapped in flame, glowed [and] burned, so burn [are being burned] these unhappy beings ... burn [are being burnt], wrapped in flame, all dear ones, clutching at teach other together. In the whole Saṃsāra, birth is not desired [any longer?], not ...
(father and mother, son and daughter) are burned, lovers clinging together, couple after couple, are burned surrounded by flames; in the whole Saṃsāra, birth is no more desired, nor (friendship),

... (there is only) suffering. Abandon, you good ones, the delights, give you up all births, leave from home, withdraw from this whole three-fold world, from the Saṃsāra! 1. || Then the venerable Maitreya, (the Buddha-god,) proclaims (to these beings)

the Law of Emptiness [śūnyatā], whereby these (beings), that have become overly world-weary, having left from home by [the] hundreds, thousands, ten thousands, myriads, towards Maitreya, the Buddha-god, ...
[they] obtain the (Srotāpanna) dignity. || Then the king Siṃha, ... having become woeful beyond all measure, (thinks) to himself: (Oh what)

p.note: Fragment with the left part to the schnurloch missing. Belongs to the same manuscript as , which follows this fragment. The manuscript as a whole includes A 251 - A 294 (cf. 64-5).
There is a gap of about 8 syllables at the beginning of this line (51).
Another gap of ca. 8 syllables at the beginning; in the gap in mid-line fragmentary remnants of a few akṣaras are still visible, which seem to form part of the end of a sentence (cf. 52 + fn. 107).
The tune Kutsmāt has a strophe of 4x12 syllables, rhythm 5/7 (54, fn. 116).
The name of the tune here called pullenaṃ is more usually spelled phullenaṃ; it has a strophe of 4x12 syllables, rhythm 7/7 (cf. 52, fn. 110; 54, fn. 117).
There is a gap of 7 syllables at the beginning of this line (52).
The tune Ṣeraśi Niṣkramānt has a strophe of 4x25 syllables, rhythm 5/5/4/4/4/3 (55, fn. 118).
There is a gap of 10 syllables at the beginning of this line (42).
There is a gap of about 14 syllables in the middle of this line (53)

div.p: Edition129-130. Siegling's personal copy of p. 129 p. 130.

list.item: a1 /// (nā)ntsuṣ nṣac wak tärnāmāṃ : ñar(eyäṃtwaṃ) /// 4 || tmäṣ āṣā(ni)k m(etrak ptāñkät) – – – a2 /// (ta)träṅkuñcäs wrasas mroskäṣlis mos(aṃ) – – – – (tāk) k(e)tuma(ti) r(i) waṣtu ṣontañ wrasañ wrasaśśi yātluneyntu • mä(nt ne tṣaṃ riñ waṣtu) a3 (ṣontañ wrasañ wrasaśśi) yātluneyntu mäskanträ • tämnek ālkontäk āṣānik metrak ptāñkät ris waṣtu ṣontas wrasas wrasaśśi yātluneyntu rä(ddhiyo pākär|pā|kär) a4 (yāmäs • täm pälkoräṣ me)trakṣiñi wrasañ cesäm ālykes|ālykes-äk mamäskuñcäs wrasas puk yātlunentuyo ṣñi ṣñi āñmaśśäl tāskmāṃ pā(kär yāmluneyo|yāmlu|neyo) a5 (añumāski nāntsu)ṣ träṅkiñc || kutsmātaṃ || # ote täpreṃ suk ; ote täpreṃ , kärparäṃ : #1a tspont yātluneyo ; śamantarr ats , napeñi : #1b wäṣt āṣānikāñ|ā(ṣā|nikāñ) a6 ; (ceṣ-äk wrasañ , wasäṃ neñc : #1c yśe) kraṃś sne kärye ; purpāc skuntu , napeṃṣās : 1 || #1d tmäṣ cem metrakṣiñi wrasañ tsmont kāckeyo tsmont yātluneyo tsmont skuntu wärpāluneyo|(wä|rpāluneyo) a7 (nermi)tṣinās risaṃ waṣtwaṃ ṣontsaṃ yātälwātses tsopats-tampes nermitṣinäs wrassaśśäl ātli k_ulewāñ tsopats mkälto lyutār memaṣ kātkmāṃ nāṃtsuṣ|(nā|ntsuṣ) a8 (sne kaś ṣiyak kalka)r || phullenaṃ|pullenaṃ || # ṣäññā ylāre , olariñ ; metrakṣiñi , mäskanträ : #1a ypanträ cesmaṃ , ortune ; ṣokyo skassuṣ , plantanträ : #1b yärkant opṣl(y)a(c) , b1 (wärpnāntär) ; %7 /// (:) #1c ceṣ kenanträ , cesäm ṣu ; cem nu cesäs , kenanträ : 1 || #1d tmäṣ ātukek nirmitṣinās risäṣ poräṃ pākär mäskanträ ñemiṣināñ riñ ñemiṣin(āñ) b2 (waṣtu ñemiṣiñi ṣontañ) śla niṣpal yātluneyaśśäl raurāp ñareyaṃ oki slamasyo wäntoṣ p_ukāk sälpiñc || täm pälkoräṣ metrakṣiñi wrasañ lyutār memaṣ|me|(maṣ) b3 (klopasuṣ nāntsuṣ tosäm) ñemiṣinās risaṃ ñemiṣinäs skāksaṃ ṣtāṅksaṃ kuccatāksaṃ kälymāṃ nirmitṣinās ris ṣärpäsmāṃ träṅkiñc hīśt tākiṣ omäskenāp|omäsken(ā)|(p) b4 (traidhātuk saṃsāris ||) ṣeraśi-niṣkramāntaṃ || # okät ñareyntu ; mät ne śla wrasas ; slamyo wäntoṣ , sälypār tskäṃṣānt ; tämne tāloṣ , ceṣ wrasañ (:) #1a b5 (pācar mācar se ; ckācar) tskäṃsanträ ; kāpñeñ kāpñeñ , yäksoṣ kaśal ; slamyo wäntoṣ ; tskäṃsanträ : #1b poñcäṃ saṃsāraṃ ; mā cmol kulypatär ; mā (ortune) , b6 %10 /// klop : #1c ptärkäs kraṃś skuntu ; prisāc puk cmolu ; pälcäs waṣtäṣ , pälycäs poñcäṃ ; traidhātuk caṣ , saṃsāräṣ : 1 || #1d tmäṣ āṣā(n)ik me(trak) b7 (ptāñkät cesäs wrasaśśi śū)nyātṣi märkampal āksiṣ kucyo ne cem ly(u)tār mām(r)oskuṣ käntantuyo wältsantuyo tmānantuyo korisyo waṣtäṣ lanturä(ṣ metrakäṃ ptāñäktac) – – – – – – b8 (srotāpattune paräṃ) kälpnānträ • || tmäṣ siṃhe wä(l) /// l(yutā)r (m)emaṣ (kl)opas(u) nāṃtsu āñmaślä(kk |ats |pältsäṅkāṣ |ote |tä)- -(preṃ)

Fragment with the left part to the schnurloch missing. Belongs to the same manuscript as [[A 256]], which follows this fragment. The manuscript as a whole includes A 251 - A 294 (cf. [[Geng et al. 2004a]]: 64-5).

Translations from [[Schmidt KT 1974]]
Lines Translation Pages
a6 (He,) [ihr] Guten! Genießet ohne Sorge die irdischen Glücksgüter! 200
a8 Sie schließen mit ihnen [wtl. zu ihnen] Freundschaft, [sind] sehr glücklich [und] freuen sich. 339
b1 Diese rufen jene herbei, jene aber rufen diese. 97, 320, 384
b4-5 Wie [da eben] die acht Höllen mit [ihren] Wesen, von der Flamme eingehüllt, glühten [und] brannten, so verbrennen [bzw. werden verbrannt] diese unglücklichen Wesen ... verbrennen [bzw. werden verbrannt], von der Flamme eingehüllt, alle Lieben, sich zusammen umklammernd. Im ganzen Saṃsāra wird nicht [mehr?] Geburt verlangt, nicht ... 133, 146-7, 243-4

b1. [[Geng et al. 2004a]]: 52 have ñemiṣināñ, we have ñemiṣināc

b2. Geng et al. have yātluneyaśśäl, we have yātluneyaśśal

b3. Geng et al. have kuccātaksaṃ, we have kuccatāksaṃ; Geng et al. have hīśt tākiṣ, we have hīst takiṣ

b8. Geng et al. have (kl)opas(u), we have (kl)opaṣ

a1 to me releasing a voice. (In the) Hells ... 4. || Then the venerable Maitreya, (the Buddha-god, made ...) a2 ... to let the beings, that are attached (to the Kleśas), feel [world-]weariness, (a mirage). (This was) the city Ketumatī, houses, streets, beings and the achievements of the beings. So as (here there are cities, houses, a3 streets, beings and) the achievements (of the beings), just so the venerable Maitreya, the Buddha-god, (by his supernatural power let appear) other cities, houses, streets, beings and achievements of the beings. a4 Having seen this, the beings of Maitreya, these other exchanged beings in all their achievements resembling themselves one by one, are a5 amazed by this manifestation, (and) they say: || In the Kutsmāt-tune: || Oh what happiness! Oh what dignity! With [their] capability [having increased], even the[se] people grow. (These very beings are to us) doubly venerable persons. a6 Hey, you good ones, enjoy without concern the delights of mortal beings! 1. || Then, these beings of Maitreya, with increased pleasure, with increased achievement (by enjoying) increased delights a7 having become joyful beyond measure, men and women, big and small, went (together) with the powerful, highly capable, fashioned beings in the[ir] fashioned cities, houses, streets (in countless numbers). a8 || In the Phulleṃ-tune: || By nature the Maitreya people are feeble companions. They make friends with them [i.e. the fashioned beings], [they are] very happy [and] rejoice. (They receive) homages for the festivity b1 ... These call those hither and those call these hither. 1. Then suddenly fires appear from the fashioned cities. The jewel-cities, the jewel-(houses) b2 (the jewel-streets), with [all] possessions and achievements shrouded in flames, burn one and all as in the Raurava-hell. || Having seen this the Maitreya people (have become woeful) beyond all measure; b3 pointing out [the inhabitants] being in the jewel-cities, in the jewel-balconies, palaces, and towers, they say: Fie on the malicious (threefold Saṃsāra)! || In the Ṣeraśi Niṣkramānt tune: || b4 Just like the eight hells together with [their] beings, shrouded by flame, glowed [and] burned, just so these miserable beings, b5 (father and mother, son and daughter) are burned, lovers clinging together, couple after couple, are burned surrounded by flames; in the whole Saṃsāra, birth is no more desired, nor (friendship), b6 ... (there is only) suffering. Abandon, you good ones, the delights, give you up all births, leave from home, withdraw from this whole three-fold world, from the Saṃsāra! 1. || Then the venerable Maitreya, (the Buddha-god,) proclaims (to these beings) b7 the Law of Emptiness [śūnyatā], whereby these (beings), that have become overly world-weary, having left from home by [the] hundreds, thousands, ten thousands, myriads, towards Maitreya, the Buddha-god, ... b8 [they] obtain the (Srotāpanna) dignity. || Then the king Siṃha, ... having become woeful beyond all measure, (thinks) to himself: (Oh what)
Gerd Carling, Georges-Jean Pinault, Hannes A. Fellner, Bernhard Koller

cf. [[Gabain 1957]]: 56.

a1. There is a gap of about 8 syllables at the beginning of this line ([[Geng et al. 2004a]]: 51).

a2. Another gap of ca. 8 syllables at the beginning; in the gap in mid-line fragmentary remnants of a few akṣaras are still visible, which seem to form part of the end of a sentence (cf. [[Geng et al. 2004a]]: 52 + fn. 107).

a5. The tune Kutsmāt has a strophe of 4x12 syllables, rhythm 5/7 ([[Geng et al. 2004a]]: 54, fn. 116).

a8. The name of the tune here called pullenaṃ is more usually spelled phullenaṃ; it has a strophe of 4x12 syllables, rhythm 7/7 (cf. [[Geng et al. 2004a]]: 52, fn. 110; 54, fn. 117).

b1. There is a gap of 7 syllables at the beginning of this line ([[Geng et al. 2004a]]: 52).

b3. The tune Ṣeraśi Niṣkramānt has a strophe of 4x25 syllables, rhythm 5/5/4/4/4/3 ([[Geng et al. 2004a]]: 55, fn. 118).

b6. There is a gap of 10 syllables at the beginning of this line ([[Geng et al. 2004a]]: 42).

b8. There is a gap of about 14 syllables in the middle of this line ([[Geng et al. 2004a]]: 53)
